ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] The truth about POST?
ygData.msgSnippet: ... It must be clear enough for the server to be able claim that the request succeeded (200 OK).  If the server doesn t know the meaning of the request, it

>> I am not requiring all that much of the term subordinate.  It just has to
>> have a clear meaning with respect to a POSTed request entity and a target
>> resource.
>
> It's clearly different from PUT.  Where is it written that it must be
> any clearer than that?

It must be clear enough for the server to be able claim that the request 
succeeded (200 OK).  If the server doesn't know the meaning of the request, 
it can't return 200 OK.  And if the meaning of the request is subject to a 
private negotiation between the server operator and the client operator, 
then there is no particular reason to use a public method name.

How else can you interpret the beginning of section 9 of RFC2616:
"""
   The set of common methods for HTTP/1.1 is defined below. Although
   this set can be expanded, additional methods cannot be assumed to
   share the same semantics for separately extended clients and servers.
"""

If POST is a catchall, it is not a "common method" it is a private method 
with a public name and client and servers cannot assume that they share the 
same semantics when the method is used.

If POST has a specific meaning then it is a "common method" for all HTTP 
clients and servers.  If you have a different specific meaning for POST, 
please share.  But if you are saying that POST has no specific meaning at 
all, then I think you are talking about a protocol other than HTTP/1.1.

-Alex-
